title: Why are hydrogen and oxygen gas and water not? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, at standard pressures, and temperatures, dihydrogen, and dioxygen are GASES, whereas water is a LIQUID. Now consider the intermolecular forces that operate between each set of molecules. Dioxygen and dihydrogen gases, and thus there is LITTLE to NO intermolecular interaction, and in fact given a molar quantity of these we can advance state functions that inter-relate pressure, volume, and temperature. On the other hand, for water, a SIGNAL INTERMOLECULAR force operates, i.e. intermolecular hydrogen-bonding. And this occurs when hydrogen is bound to a STRONGLY electronegative element, viz. nitrogen, or fluorine, or OXYGEN. Because oxygen is quite electronegative, water acts as a molecular dipole, as the oxygen polarizes electron-density towards itself…and we can attempt to represent this… [math]^{+\delta}H-\stackrel{\delta-}O-H^{\delta+}[/math] …and in the bulk phase, these dipoles line up, and this interaction constitutes a potent intermolecular force … [math]H-O-H \cdots OH_{2} \cdots OH_{2} \cdots[/math] Note that ammonia, [math]NH_{3}[/math], and hydrogen fluoride, [math]HF[/math], also have unusually elevated boiling points attributable to this hydrogen-bonding interaction. You should look up the normal boiling points, and compare them to the hydrides of the LOWER Group 15, and Group 17 hydrides…

response.answer_text: Every element, every molecule has a gas, a liquid and a solid phase based on pressure and temperature. Earth’s “normal” temperature and pressure ranges dictate gas phase for hydrogen and oxygen; liquid phase for water. That is the only answer. And that is the ONLY reason hydrogen and oxygen are gasses but water is a liquid. At above 100°C Hydrogen, Oxygen and water are all gasses. At below O°C water is a solid while the Oxygen and Hydrogen are gasses. At -259.14°C Hydrogen, Oxygen and are liquids. Water is solid. But we don’t exist in THOSE surroundings. Other planets, stars, moons, asteroids and comets will have varying “normal” temperatures and pressures. But for our “normal” pressures and temperatures hydrogen and oxygen are gasses. And water is a liquid.
